free_text.Learning outcomes: Continuous downscaling of MOSFET devices represents a challenge to the modeling community since these require both accurate and 'simple' models in order to be used for advanced circuit design. Indeed, there is actually a gap between technology achievements and their corresponding so called 'compact' models. Basically, moving toward nanometric architecture raises different problems, requiring a fine description of the device from its electrical characteristics. Also classical drift-diffusion equations, widely used to describe electronic transport in semicon-ductor based devices, show their limit and should be replaced by new concepts. In this context, this course will present a general overview of the most widely used approaches that address analytical modeling of micro- and nanometer scaled field effect electron devices.

[br/]            General charge based partitionning principle (transcapacitances)[br/]   II)  The concept of inversion charge linearization in bulk MOSFETs (EKV approach)[br/]             Static and non quasi static small signal solutions[br/]             Polydepletion and quantum corrections[br/][br/]B) Modelling advanced multgate MOSFETs.[br/]   I)  Double gate architectures[br/]             General electrostatic solution, symmetrical/assymetrical operation[br/]             Quantum confinement corrections in ultra thin devices (<10 nm)[br/]   II)  Modelling cylindrical MOSFETs and carbon nanotube based devices[br/]              Classical solution and its correlation with symmetrical double gate[br/]              From quantum well to quantum wire strcuture[br/]C)  Modelling electronic transport in nano devices[br/]              Ballistic transport [br/]              Introduction to quantum conductance[br/]
